What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may l

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrsry example is the protagonis of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thoiman Be

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is mastwerfully

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is mastwerfully plotted, but the main character isa  c

Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him, di

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline cringeworthy, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him a didn;t care what hapepned to him.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn;t care what hapepned to him. He could hasve been anyone.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline sociopathic, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So tha

And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline sociopathic, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So that's the test that matters: i

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline sociopathic, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So that's the test that matters: is he character eral/ Do youi  c

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So that's the test that matters: is he character real.  Do you  care about them?

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline sociopathic, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So that's the test that matters: is he character real.  Do you  care about them? If youi talk to good asuthor

I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So that's the test that matters: is he character real.  Do you  care about them? If youi talk to good asuthor, they invariably say that theeir characters have a life

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline sociopathic, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So that's the test that matters: is he character real.  Do you  care about them? If youi talk to good asuthor, they invariably say that theeir characters have a life of there own, and do things wi

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, what makes a character portrayal offensive is its unreality. And there's an easy test for that: If I am reading or watching a movie and I find that I have not developed empathy for a character, then that character has likely been portrayed in a way that is not fully formed, and hence is unreal.

An example of a "real" character is the portrayal of Captain Hastings, played by Adrian Dunbar, in the BBC/Acorn show Line of Duty. Captains Hastings is not likeable, in fact borderline sociopathic, but he is real and I found myself caring deeply what happens to him in spite of my personal dislike of him.
I think that's the key to a good portrayal of a character:
 you may like or hate them, but you care.

A contrary example is the protagonist of the fiction book "The Good Lawyer" by Thomas Benigno. The book is masterfully plotted, but the main character is a  cipher. I didn't relate to him and didn't care what happened to him. He could have been anyone. The book suffered and so did the reader.

So that's the test that matters: is he character real.  Do you  care about them? Grea invariably say that their characters have a life of there own, and do things without the author intending them to do so.
